title: This is what happens when Riot listens to the community.
body:
People were tired of stall comps, so Riot has steadily weakened towers so that stall comps are significantly harder to pull off. 

People found the games were dragging on too long, so Riot made the games faster. 

People wanted an end to a tanky meta, so Riot created the exact opposite type of meta. 

People disliked soloqueue, so Riot's changed that as well. 

People complained about warding and the struggle to remember their upgrade, so Riot gave a version of the upgrade for free.

People felt that top was too isolated, so Rift Herald was implemented.

People viewed ADC itemization and playstyles as stale, so they revamped them entirely.

I'm sure there's more examples to be given, but the point is that Riot has given us the things we asked for. It might not be in the exact specific way you imagined it being, Riot heard our wish and granted it. Maybe next time we should be a little more careful what we wish for.

My only point was that people shouldn't be acting like ping makes sufficient difference to impact ranked, and that the limiting factor for a large majority of people is how fast they can react, not the latency on their internet connection.

50 or 60ms can make a difference, but once you go below about 40ms (a little less than 1/24th of a second), it becomes mostly irrelevant because the human brain can only process images from the eyes at the equivalent of about 12fps (60 is the gold standard because it's high enough that almost all animations look perfectly smooth to almost all people, and in the US TV ran at 60fps because the power line frequency was 60Hz, thus making the design of the television easier).  Because of the Nyquist limit, people won't see much difference below 1/24th of a second ping (although if they know what the actual ping is, they may think they see a difference, because of the placebo effect).  If you can find some software that lets you view animated GIF's at arbitrary frame rates, try watching one at 24 fps, then try at 6 fps, then try at 60.  You'll see a very noticeable difference between 24fps and 6fps, but probably not much between 24 and 60 (other than it obviously looking faster at 60fps).

Alright, say someone asks you to make a poster for an event. You agree, then a week later show up at his house with the poster. Said person takes it, and .... It's horrible.

Now in a normal situation, most people would say "you asked the wrong guy". Which isn't wrong, but in Riot's case, it simply doesn't work that way. Riot is the only one that can answer to people's feedback and ideas.

Forums might have asked for less stall comps, shorter games and whatnot, but that doesn't mean it's been done correctly. And in this case it's perfectly acceptable to call Riot out on it. In fact, they want us to do so. They might not answer much, but our opinion of the game is still important to them.

Also, a lot of the more annoying changes were actually uncalled for. Mastery changes, mana pots, sightstone nerf, even the tower nerfs (though I have a feeling that's more of a "change went bad" than "we just nerfed it") are examples that come to mind.

Pinks are fine, but some supports are better at protecting them than others, and matchups can make defending one impossible to begin with. 

And what did we get in exchange? Being able to fuse it with our gold gen item? Would be sweet if we didn't lose the item active. Apart from frost queen, both FotM and Talisman are waaaay too good to pass up on. If anything I'd have merged it with Trinket :
Yellow : Wards regen naturally (1 per 2 min so you still have to back)
Red : If you mouseover your character while "dropping" a ward it activates the true sight aura temporarily
Blue : Lets you drop a Blue ward if out of normal ward range but in the blue trinket range (Maybe give some buffer range so players don't accidently drop their blue ward for clicking a bit too far out of normal ward range, but not a core necessity)
